etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Arthur Cayley (1821–1895), mathematician. From auto- + -morphic

definitions: Of a function: invariant with respect to a group of linear transformations of a certain kind. Of a transformation: †leaving a certain function invariant (obsolete).

notes.text: In modern use, if a function f(x) is automorphic with respect to a group G, then f(Tₙ(x)) = f(x) for every element Tₙ of G. This use originated with F. Klein.

definitions: Characterized by automorphism; formed on oneself.
Designating an n -digit number which when raised to a power gives a number whose last n digits are the same as the original number.

notes.text: E.g. 5 is automorphic because 52 is 25, 53 is 125, 54 is 625, etc.; 76 is automorphic because 762 is 5776, 763 is 438,976, etc.
